Matter and souls form the body of God, and this body is capable of existing in a subtle as well as gross condition.ğŸ”½God with His subtle body constitutes the universe in its causal condition, and with His gross body He forms the created universe itself. original: God enters into matter and soul and gives them theirğŸ”½powers and their specific characters / The universeğŸ”½without God is exactly analogous to matter withoutğŸ”½soul and in the world / as we know it / all things areğŸ”½what they are / because God has penetrated into them
analyzed: god enters into mattra and soul and gives them their ğŸ”½powers and their specific characters the univese ğŸ”½is exactly analogous to matter without ğŸ”½soul and in the world as we know it all things are ğŸ”½they are because god has penetrated into them
translated: The universe, consisting of matter and soul, is the effect produced by Him. Matter and souls form the body of God, and this body is capable of existing in a subtle as well as gross condition. God with His subtle body constitutes the universe in its causal condition, and with His gross body He forms the created universe itself. The individual souls enter into matter and thereby make it live. Similarly God enters into matter and soul and gives them their powers and specific characters. The universe without God is exactly analogous to matter without soul, and in the world as we know it, all things are what they are because God has penetrated into them.

translated: Greatness and whatever greatness there is, by nature as well as by qualities. Unsurpassable in excellence. That is its primary and natural meaning. And he who possesses such greatness is alone the Lord of all. Hence the word Brahman is primarily used to signify Him alone. In cases where, on account of the association of a modicum of that quality, other things than the Lord are meant by the word Brahman, it must have been used in a secondary sense, because it is improper to postulate a variety of meanings for it, as it is improper in the case of the word Bhagavat also. He is the Supreme Self known as Narayana, whose abode is Sri Vaikuntha and whose consort is Sri or Mahalakshmi.

translated: He was a well-known celebrated being. His celebrity includes the twofold causation said above. Consider the existence alone of the text. My dear boy, this was in the beginning only, without a second. It thought, 'May I become many and be born.' It created fire. Here the expression 'existence alone, this was in the beginning only' proves that He is the material cause of the universe. The expression 'without a second' refutes a different substratum. Hence it becomes known that the Brahman, who is denoted by the word 'existence,' is both the efficient cause and the material cause of the universe. It is also known from the scriptural text 'It thought, May I become many and be born (Ch. Up. 6.2.3).
